all_paragraphs: With the current outbreak of the Coronavirus going on, we hear a lot about Exponential Growth. In this article, I show how to understand and analyze Exponential Growth. If you want to follow along, you can use those example data and a short Python notebook.

Exponential Growth is a mathematical function that can be used in several situations. The formula tells us the number of cases at a certain moment in time, in the case of Coronavirus, this is the number of infected people.
In other use cases of exponential growth, this number could be the size of an animal population or the value on your bank account (if you are lucky enough to have good interest rates).

The reason to use Exponential Growth for modeling the Coronavirus outbreak is that epidemiologists have studied those types of outbreaks and it is well known that the first period of an epidemic follows Exponential Growth.

If we want to represent this graphically, we start to see a graph that looks a lot like the very alarming curves that we see concerning the Coronavirus:

Now, we know that this graph has more or less the right shape, but we need to make an additional step to make our analysis useful. We need to find the real growth factor of the Corona epidemic, by looking at the data from the epidemic spread.

When looking at the data, we only have the number of cases per day, and not the growth factor. The best method to find the growth factor from empirical daily observations is to use a statistical model called Linear Regression.

Now that we have estimated this new formula, we can use it to make predictions for any date that we want. It’s important to note that the predictions here are only an example to show how mathematics and statistics could be used in epidemiology. Real life epidemiologists would test different types of models besides exponential growth and do extensive work on model validation, while this has not been done for the current example.

Once the best model has been found, it can be used for prediction. Using the function that we have estimated using the Exponential Growth curve, if we want to predict for 2 weeks after the last day of the dataset, day 68, we simply put t= 68 into the formula and the model predicts 3355 infections on that day.
